marketNews.title: Trump Pauses Tariffs for 56 Countries, Tariff for China Increases to 125%
marketNews.content: U.S. President Donald Trump announced on Wednesday (April 9 local time) a temporary suspension of the implementation of higher reciprocal tariffs for 56 countries for a period of 90 days. However, the tariff for China remains in effect and is increased from 104% to 125% in response to Chinese retaliatory actions. In addition, Trump continues the basic reciprocal tariff of 10% for all imports into the United States. The tariff postponement comes amid financial market panic and growing pressure from business owners and investors to cancel the policy. Previously, on Tuesday (April 8) Trump hinted that the United States was open to reaching an agreement that could reduce or eliminate the higher reciprocal tariffs. On Wednesday (April 9) Trump added that countries that do not take retaliatory steps will be given a reward. The decision to keep the higher reciprocal tariff for China occurs amid an escalating trade war between the two nations. Earlier, the Chinese government on Wednesday (April 9) announced an increase in tariffs on U.S. imports from 34% to 84% effective April 10, 2025, and stated it would take the United States to the World Trade Organization (WTO). This follows a U.S. tariff increase imposed on China after China took retaliatory steps. On Thursday (April 10), a spokesperson for the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Lin Jian, said that the U.S. decision to start a trade war with China will end in failure, but added that the Chinese government hopes the United States can resolve differences with China through dialogue. To date, China has not announced any retaliatory tariff increase after the United States applied a 125% tariff. Domestically, Finance Minister Sri Mulyani said on Thursday (April 10) that the 32% tariff imposed by the United States on Indonesia could cut Indonesia's potential economic growth by about 0.3 to 0.5 percentage points. She welcomed the 90-day tariff suspension, describing the period as an opportunity to negotiate, reduce economic risk, and build mutually beneficial cooperation. In response to Trump’s announcement, U.S. equity markets rebounded sharply on Wednesday (April 9) with the S&P 500 up 9.52% and the Nasdaq up 12.16%. The positive sentiment spread to Asian markets on Thursday (April 10), with the Nikkei up 8.99%, the Shanghai Stock Exchange up 1.16%, and the Hong Kong Index up 2.06%. The Indonesian Composite Index (IHSG) closed up 4.79% on Thursday (April 10), the Indonesian rupiah strengthened by 0.38% to 16,800 per U.S. dollar, and the yield on the 10-year Indonesian government bond fell about 9 basis points to 7.048%. Key Takeaway: Although the 90-day pause provides time for negotiations, we assess that the outcome of negotiations and the shift in stance by both the United States and China remain highly dynamic. Japan and South Korea are reported to have been negotiating with the United States, which may serve as a reference for other countries, so developments should be closely monitored by investors. Investors should remain vigilant and respond wisely to both positive and negative news related to the trade war, given the high uncertainty. Maintaining a diversified portfolio across asset classes can help minimize market volatility impact. Investors may consider short-term government bonds with lower volatility, such as PBS003 and ST014-T2, or money-market mutual funds.

marketNews.title: President Prabowo meets PDI-P Chair Megawati for first time in over a year
marketNews.content: President Prabowo Subianto met with the Chair of the Indonesian Democratic Party of Struggle (PDI-P), Megawati Soekarnoputri, for the first time in more than a year. The meeting took place on Monday (April 7), although officials later said it actually occurred about one day later. The head of the Gerindra Party’s daily executive board, Sufmi Dasco Ahmad, said that President Prabowo and Megawati exchanged thoughts and experiences during the meeting, without providing further details. PDI-P is currently the only opposition party remaining, and Bloomberg reported that the meeting signaled that PDI-P could join President Prabowo’s coalition. However, PDI-P spokesperson Guntur Romli hoped that the meeting would not be misinterpreted as the party joining the coalition.

marketNews.title: China consumer price index shows deflation in March 2025
marketNews.content: China’s National Bureau of Statistics reported that the consumer price index (CPI) recorded a deflation of 0.1% year-on-year in March 2025 (compared with a 0.7% YoY deflation in February 2025), contrary to consensus expectations of a flat annual rate and marking a second consecutive month of annual deflation. On a month-to-month basis, China recorded a CPI deflation of 0.4% (versus a 0.2% MoM deflation in February 2025), worse than the consensus expectation of a 0.3% MoM deflation and indicating a second consecutive month of monthly deflation. Meanwhile, core inflation rose to 0.5% YoY, reversing from a 0.1% YoY deflation in February 2025.

marketNews.title: EU member states approve 25% tariffs on US imports
marketNews.content: European Union member states on Wednesday (April 9) approved a 25% tariff on various US import products, including almonds, orange juice, poultry, soybeans, steel and aluminium, tobacco and cruise ships. The measure is a retaliation against the 25% tariff imposed by the United States on EU steel and aluminium imports since March 12, 2025. The EU tariffs on the United States will take effect between April 15 and December 1, 2025, providing an opportunity for negotiations with the US government.

marketNews.title: Indonesia housing minister announces new low-income criteria for subsidized homes
marketNews.content: Indonesia’s Minister of Housing and Settlement Areas, Maruarar Sirait, said on Tuesday (April 8) that the ministry will change the income criteria for low-income households (MBR) who receive subsidized housing. Under the new criteria, the maximum income for single low-income households will be set at 12 million rupiah per month, and for married low-income households at 13 million rupiah per month. Previously, the maximum income for single households was 7 million rupiah per month and for married households 8 million rupiah per month. Maruarar said the change will initially apply to the Greater Jakarta area, and the new regulation will be released no later than April 21, 2025.

tickerNews.title: LPPF announces 2024 dividend of Rp300 per share, indicating 15.2% yield
tickerNews.content: $LPPF: Matahari Department Store plans to distribute a 2024 dividend of approximately 677.5 billion rupiah or 300 rupiah per share, representing about an 82% dividend payout ratio. The cum-date is on the regular market and negotiation market on April 21, 2025, with payment on April 29, 2025. Based on LPPF’s closing price of 1,975 rupiah per share on Thursday (April 10), the implied dividend yield is 15.2%.

tickerNews.title: JPFA shareholders approve final dividend for 2024, indicating ~3.5% yield
tickerNews.content: $JPFA: Shareholders of Japfa Comfeed Indonesia approved a final dividend for the 2024 fiscal year of 813.9 billion rupiah or 70 rupiah per share on Thursday (April 10). The cum-date and payment date have not been announced. Based on JPFA’s closing price of 1,970 rupiah per share on Thursday (April 10), the implied final dividend yield is approximately 3.5%. Previously, JPFA distributed an interim dividend for 2024 of 813.9 billion rupiah or 70 rupiah per share in October 2024. In addition, shareholders approved a share buyback of up to 2% of issued and paid-up capital, with a maximum fund allocation of 470 billion rupiah, to be discussed at the extraordinary shareholders meeting on April 10, 2025.

tickerNews.title: MTEL reports 4Q24 net profit of Rp575 billion and outlines 2025 guidance
tickerNews.content: $MTEL: Dayamitra Telekomunikasi recorded a net profit of 575 billion rupiah in 4Q24 (down 1% year-on-year, up 23% quarter-on-quarter). This result brought total 2024 net profit to 2.1 trillion rupiah, a 5% year-on-year increase, in line with the 100% consensus estimate for 2024. The total fiber-optic network length grew from 32,000 km to 51,000 km during 2024 (a 57% year-on-year increase), mainly due to the acquisition of 12,500 km of billable fiber-optic length from PT Ultra Mandiri Telekomunikasi in December 2024. In the earnings call on Thursday (April 10), MTEL management provided guidance for revenue and EBITDA growth in the low single-digit range for 2025 as a conservative step amid macro-economic volatility and industry consolidation. Management also gave a capital-expenditure guidance of 5.3 trillion rupiah for 2025, targeting a tenant growth of 2,500 (up 4% year-on-year from 2024) and an addition of 10,000 km of fiber-optic network (up 20% year-on-year from 2024).

tickerNews.title: SMGR plans share buyback up to Rp300 billion and proposes 80% dividend payout for 2024
tickerNews.content: $SMGR: Management of Semen Indonesia announced in an analyst meeting on Thursday (April 10) that the company will soon conduct a share buyback with a fund allocation of up to 300 billion rupiah, although the maximum number of shares to be repurchased and the buyback period have not been disclosed. The corporate action does not require a shareholders’ meeting, following the relaxation granted by the Financial Services Authority (OJK) to support market stability. Management also plans to propose a dividend payout ratio of 80% for the 2024 fiscal year (compared with 26.4% in 2023), corresponding to a dividend of 85 rupiah per share and indicating an approximate dividend yield of 4% based on SMGR’s share price on Thursday (April 10). The extraordinary shareholders’ meeting will be held in May 2025.

tickerNews.title: AKRA directors purchase shares totaling approx Rp9.9 billion in early April 2025
tickerNews.content: $AKRA: Members of the board of directors and commissioners of AKR Corporindo – Soegiarto Adikoesoemo, Haryanto Adikoesoemo, and Jimmy Tandyo – each bought shares of AKRA. Soegiarto purchased 7.3 million shares at an average price of 966 rupiah per share, Haryanto bought 1 million shares at 900 rupiah per share, and Jimmy bought 2 million shares at 990 rupiah per share during April 8-9, 2025. The total value of the three transactions is approximately 9.9 billion rupiah. After the transactions, Soegiarto’s direct ownership increased from 0.67% to 0.71%, Haryanto’s from 1.024% to 1.029%, and Jimmy’s from 0.2% to 0.21%.

tickerNews.title: CLEO shares increase as PT Tancorp Global Abadi buys 31.9 million shares
tickerNews.content: $CLEO: The controlling shareholder Sariguna Primatirta, through PT Tancorp Global Abadi, purchased 31.9 million shares of CLEO at a price of 1,290 rupiah per share on March 27, 2025. The total transaction value is approximately 41.1 billion rupiah. After the transaction, PT Tancorp Global Abadi’s ownership in CLEO rose from 55.86% to 56.12%.

tickerNews.title: MAPA director purchases 900,000 shares at Rp555 each
tickerNews.content: $MAPA: Director of Map Aktif Adiperkasa, Miquel Rodrigo Staal, bought 900,000 shares of MAPA at a price of 555 rupiah per share on April 9, 2025. The total transaction value is about 500 million rupiah. After the transaction, Staal’s ownership in MAPA increased from 0.049% to 0.052%.

tickerNews.title: ANJT targets 15% YoY increase in CPO production for 2025
tickerNews.content: $ANJT: Austindo Nusantara Jaya reported that it targets a 15% year-on-year increase in crude palm oil (CPO) production during 2025. The company’s CPO production in 2024 fell 13.5% year-on-year to 245,395 tons, mainly due to prolonged dry weather in several operational areas.

tickerNews.title: SGRO announces share buyback up to Rp450 billion between 9 April and 8 July 2025
tickerNews.content: $SGRO: Sampoerna Agro announced a share buyback program with a fund allocation of up to 450 billion rupiah, to be carried out between April 9 and July 8, 2025. The corporate action does not require a shareholders’ meeting, following the relaxation granted by the Financial Services Authority (OJK) to support market stability.
